title: How to Put Your Life Back Together After a Fire

steps.headline: Contact disaster relief services and charitable organizations.
steps.description: In the days after a fire, a disaster relief service, such as your local Red Cross chapter, can help you pay for a hotel, clothing, toiletries, and other necessities. Other helpful resources include government emergency services agencies, your state or province’s public health department, and faith-based organizations. You can find your local Red Cross chapter here: http://www.redcross.org/find-your-local-chapter

steps.headline: Reach out to family, friends, and coworkers.
steps.description: Your loved ones could give you a place to stay, help you pay for new clothes and furniture, and lend you emotional support. Tell your boss and coworkers about your situation, and ask for time off or to have someone cover an important project. Your coworkers might also be able to donate paid vacation days so you can take some time to relax and manage your affairs. steps.headline: Set up a crowdfunding campaign.
steps.description: Crowdfunding can help you get the financial support you’ll need to bounce back after a fire. It’s quick and easy to set up a GoFundMe or other online campaign. Promote it on social media, and have your friends and family share your campaign with their social networks. You could also contact your local news channel and ask them to share your crowdfunding page.

steps.headline: Try traditional fundraising techniques.
steps.description: In addition to an online crowdfunding campaign, you could organize fundraisers on your own or with a community organization's help. Fundraising efforts could range from passing out a donation form at work or school to raising money by hosting a ticketed event. For example, if you're a member of a church or other faith-based organization, look into putting together a ticketed event, like a dinner. To reduce costs and maximize proceeds, food could be donated and prepared by other members or a local restaurant.

steps.headline: File a claim with your insurer.
steps.description: Filing a claim with your homeowner’s or rental insurance is the first step to rebuilding your finances and replacing your possessions. When you call your insurance agent, ask for detailed instructions about how to document damage, contact restoration companies and contractors, and conduct repairs. If you don’t have insurance, you’ll have to rely on your community’s support. It might be a little more difficult to bounce back without insurance, but remember you’re not alone. Your loved ones, disaster relief services, community organizations, and government agencies can help you get back on your feet.

steps.headline: Stop utility services and other expenses.
steps.description: If your home was destroyed or is uninhabitable, shut off your electricity, internet, and other utilities as soon as possible. Cutting these expenses will help you save money for a security deposit and rent, food, clothes, and new furniture.

steps.headline: Get out of your lease if your rental unit is unlivable.
steps.description: If you’re a renter, discuss the situation with your landlord as soon as possible. If your home is unlivable, they might have another unit you can rent, but make sure they agree in writing that you won’t be responsible for paying rent for both places. Laws vary by location, but if your home is unlivable, you can usually get out of a lease without much trouble. If a fire marshal or inspector determined the unit is unlivable, get a copy of their report. If your landlord tries to take you to court for the remainder of your lease, the report will lead to a quick dismissal of their case. Further, if you can prove that your landlord knew of an issue that caused the fire, such as faulty wiring, their insurance company will also have to replace your belongings.

steps.headline: Ask for extensions from your lenders and creditors.
steps.description: You’re required to report your loss if you have a mortgage, but you should also ask your lender to stop requiring payments for a limited time. Most credit card companies will also give you a grace period if you contact them promptly. That way, you can get your finances back in shape without hurting your credit score.

steps.headline: Document the damage.
steps.description: Take photographs and video of your damaged property. Don’t throw away anything until you’ve provided your insurer with documentation and a claims adjuster has inspected the site. Make sure the fire department has determined that the site is safe before you check the damage.

steps.headline: Track down store and bank records to support your inventory.
steps.description: It’s wise to take photographs and video of all of your possessions before a disaster. If you don’t have prior documentation of your belongings, make a list of everything you own that was damaged in the fire. Find evidence of how much you paid for items by combing through your bank and credit card statements and asking stores for records of your purchases. Taking a detailed inventory of your damaged property can be a painstaking process. However, it’s an essential part of getting the biggest insurance payout possible.

steps.headline: Save receipts for all fire-related purchases.
steps.description: If you spend any money out of pocket on clothing, toiletries, rent, and other necessities, you can get compensated by your insurer as long as you have receipts. In addition, you’ll need the receipts in order to report fire-related losses when you file your taxes.

steps.headline: Look for inexpensive items online and at thrift shops.
steps.description: If you’re not insured, replacing clothing, furniture, and other belongings can seem impossible. While your loved ones and community can offer support, you should try to get the biggest bang for your buck. Craigslist, consignment shops, and thrift stores are good places to look for affordable secondhand furniture, appliances, and clothing. You can also look for free items on The Freecycle Network: https://www.freecycle.org/. steps.headline: Replace licenses, certificates, credit cards, and other vital documents.
steps.description: Make a list of important documents that were lost in the fire, then get in touch with the appropriate agencies to replace them. It might be tedious, but you’ll need to call your bank or credit card company, head to your department of motor vehicles, and visit your local bureau of records. The Red Cross has a helpful guide about how to replace documents from driver’s licenses to property deeds: http://www.redcross.org/get-help/disaster-relief-and-recovery-services/recovering-financially.

steps.headline: Work closely with your insurer if you need to rebuild your house.
steps.description: Your mortgage or homeowner’s association will probably require you to rebuild your home. Have your insurance agent explain your responsibilities and outline the rebuilding process. Get the names of licensed contractors from your insurer, and check out their listings on the Better Business Bureau to make sure they’re competent. The rebuilding process varies by insurance company, so talk to your agent about your insurer’s specific procedures.

steps.headline: Allow yourself to experience both positive and negative emotions.
steps.description: Give yourself permission to experience sadness, anger, and frustration. While it’s normal and necessary to grieve, try to focus on positive emotions. Look for things you can be thankful for, from surviving the fire to having the support of your community.

steps.headline: Try to maintain your physical health.
steps.description: Putting your life back together after a fire is stressful and time consuming, so make sure you take care of yourself. Do your best to eat healthy meals and rest. While there’s a lot to do, try to take some time to relax and do activities you enjoy.

steps.headline: Encourage your children to talk about their emotions.
steps.description: If you have children, let them know that it’s okay to feel afraid, sad, and upset, and that they can talk to you about anything. Tell them that these emotions are normal, and that they are safe and everything will gradually return to normal.

steps.headline: Do your best to return to personal routines.
steps.description: After handling details like insurance claims and paperwork, try to settle back into your daily routines. School, work, exercise, and hanging out with loved ones can help you regain a sense of normalcy. Getting back into a routine is especially helpful for children.

steps.headline: Look for a support group or counselor.
steps.description: Sharing your emotions with loved ones is helpful, but you might want to talk to someone with a deeper understanding of your situation. Contact your local disaster relief service or look online for a support group for survivors of fires and other disasters. You could also talk to a counselor or therapist who has experience helping people recover from traumatic events.
